name: Jaquarrius Holland
bio:
Jaquarrius Holland, an 18-year-old transgender woman living in Monroe, Louisiana, was murdered on Feb. 19 and, due to initial misgendering, was not reported as transgender.

Holland also went by the name Jaquarrius Brown and often used the hashtag #PrettyBrown when she'd post pictures of herself.

Holland's friend Chesna Littleberry said Holland's favorite singer was R&B artist K. Michelle and that she loved to sing along to her songs. The two hoped to attend a K. Michelle concert together one day.

Littleberry called Holland the "eyelash queen" because she always wore eyelashes out of the house. She also loved to do makeup and hairstyling.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Ciara McElveen
bio:
Ciara McElveen was stabbed to death in New Orleans.

Her death came only two days after the death of Chyna Doll Dupree and sent shockwaves throughout the New Orleans community.

In a statement to Mic, New Orleans trans advocacy group BreakOUT! said, "We have so much other work to do in our communities — we need jobs, housing, education and access to safe spaces — and yet we continue to have to simply fight for our lives."

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Chyna Doll Dupree
bio:
Chyna Doll Dupree was shot and killed outside of a shopping center in New Orleans while she was visiting family to celebrate Mardi Gras. She went by the name Chyna Gibson on Facebook.

Dupree was also a drag performer who entertained for a living. In the wake of her death, many people shared videos of her routines on social media.

"My heart breaks as this community must find a way to honor you in death and begin to move forward," one person wrote about Dupree's death. "The stage will never be the same!"

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Keke Collier
bio:
24-year-old trans woman Keke Collier was shot and killed in Chicago's Englewood neighborhood. She also went by the name Tiara Richmond.

Police say the circumstances of her death are unknown and they are still investigating Collier's death.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Jamie Lee Wounded Arrow
bio:
According to local activists, the death of Jamie Lee Wounded Arrow, 28, in January 2017 is the first reported homicide of a transgender woman in South Dakota.

At the time of her death, Wounded Arrow was in talks to join TransAction South Dakota to conduct outreach to First Nation transgender people.

Wounded Arrow was originally from the Pine Ridge Reservation in South Dakota and belonged to the Oglala Lakota tribe.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: India Monroe
bio:
India Monroe, 29, was killed on Dec. 21, 2016, in Newport News, Virginia. Initial reports misgendered Monroe.

Police are currently investigating Monreo's death as a domestic incident, not a hate crime.

Friends of Monroe who attended her funeral on Jan. 3, 2017, said that the family chose to bury Monroe under her name and gender assigned at birth. Monroe's hair had been cut, gloves covered her hands and she wore a blue suit.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Mesha Caldwell
bio:
Mesha Caldwell, 41, was a beautician and hairstylist living in Canton, Mississippi. She was found dead on Wednesday, January 4, 2017, and initially misgendered in media reports.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Monica Loera
bio:
Monica Loera, 43, had three passions: fashion, makeup and Madonna. A Mexican-American woman with long brown hair that she often wore in curls, Monica engaged in sex work to pay the bills.

She knew how to create an outfit, even if it meant turning a skirt into a shirt. She helped less fashion-forward friends put themselves together. Before a date, Monica would do her friends’ makeup and wardrobe.

Makeup and styling was just one of the ways Monica treated her friends generously. One time, after Monica came into a large amount of money, she took her friends shopping, bought them clothes and rented a hotel room so they could all live in luxury for a day. She also loved to cook Mexican food for her friends.

Monica was shot at her home by a man she barely knew in February — the first recorded trans murder of 2016. She died later that night in the hospital.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Jasmine Sierra
bio:
To those who knew her, Jasmine Sierra, 52, was the snarkiest, funniest woman they’d ever met. Despite the fact that her only income was a disability check she received because of diabetes, Sierra handed out cigarettes and dollar bills to the many people who would knock on her door looking for help.

But according to one of her close friends, Jasmine’s friendly demeanor masked a loneliness only those closest to her saw. Jasmine trusted someone in the complex with the knowledge of her gender identity. Once they betrayed her trust, she became a joke. Young kids from her apartment complex who had heard rumors about the transgender woman living nearby would knock on the door to gawk at her and giggle when she answered.

“They just come here to stare at me because I’m a freak of nature,” she once told a friend.

Despite these setbacks, Jasmine continued to be a positive force in the lives of others. She would often play mother to younger trans girls and bring them with her to the local community health clinic in Bakersfield, California, to get STI tests and procure condoms.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Crystal Edmonds
bio:
Crystal Edmonds lived and breathed Baltimore’s ballroom scene — a niche community composed primarily of black LGBTQ people who compete in runway contests. The 32-year-old was the mother of the House of Gotti, a mentor to the rest of the house family.

“But she was like my mom on the outside of the house as well,” Tamar Winter Jones said.

“Having a mom and dad in the gay life is very important — I look at it as very important — because I can’t go home to my [childhood] father or my mom and talk about my life or be around them as the transgender woman that I am,” Tamar said. “But I could go to talk to [my dad and Crystal] and be myself and not get judged at all.”

Tamar described Crystal as a positive, loving person who never held back from telling it like it is. When Tamar was first transitioning and vying for acceptance into the House of Gotti, she said, Crystal met with her at a house meeting and promptly told her she needed to work on her wardrobe.

“It was in a nice way,” Tamar said. “I wanted to be in the house.”

Even during that first meeting, she added, Crystal’s “realness” was much like genuine maternal instinct.

“She was telling me to take my hormones, don’t take no drugs off the street,” Tamar said. “She was a good mentor, basically.”

The most important lesson Crystal taught Tamar, she said, was to never lie to yourself or to anyone about who you are — and, above all else, to never be ashamed of it.

Crystal died after being shot in the back of the head in northwest Baltimore in September.

— Brianna Provenzano

name: Demarkis Stansberry
bio:
30-year-old Demarkis Stansberry believed that he served God through his music. He performed on stage locally, rapping under the name “Righzous.”

Demarkis was shy and quiet, but lit up in the studio around his musical equipment. He carried a notebook around with him to jot down lyrics. He also kept drawings: detailed renderings of R&B singer Aaliyah, 3-D flowers and anime characters. He also painted T-shirts and designed logos for record labels and entertainment companies he hoped to own in the future.

Demarkis always wore a hat, along with jeans and a button down. He worked at a Taco Bell, but his passion was hearty Italian food — especially pasta and meatballs — which he learned to cook himself by watching Food Network.

Demarkis was shy, but lit up around friends. He often teased loved ones by giving them nicknames. He would tell his friends, “My goal is to get on your nerves at least once a day.”

Demarkis was shot in the head by a friend’s brother on Feb. 27. The shooter turned himself in to police, saying he thought the weapon was empty at the time.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Jazz Alford
bio:
Jazz Alford, 30, had a deep love of God. She often tried to bring friends, especially other transgender girls, with her to worship where she lived in Winston-Salem, North Carolina.

She loved to sing gospel. Her favorite songs were “I Need You to Survive” by Hezekiah Walker and “(Life and Favor) You Don’t Know My Story” by John P. Kee.

Jazz practiced music in more ways than just singing: Students at High Point Central High School knew her for her dancing skills, especially for her ability to dance the “percolator.” She idolized beautiful, positive women like Sanaa Lathan, Tyra Banks and Beyoncé.

When Jazz's brother, Mitchell, announced to his family that he wanted an iPad for Christmas, Jazz was the one who scrounged together the money to get it for him.

Jazz worked as a reservation agent at U.S. Airways, where she transitioned publicly. She also traveled frequently, especially to Atlanta and Philadelphia, where she loved to hang out around South Street. She told a friend of hers from Philadelphia, “Your home is like my second home.”

Jazz was found shot at the Kings Inn in Birmingham, Alabama, on Sept. 23.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Kedarie "Kandicee" Johnson
bio:
Kedarie, a 16-year-old who also went by Kandicee, identified as transgender and gender-fluid. Shaunda Campbell, a high school counselor, said she took Kedarie “under my wing,” and Kedarie became one of the kids that showed up at her desk all the time. The teen was “definitely a diva, he liked being flashy, he liked being the center of attention,” Shaunda said. But Kedarie also liked to help others. Shaunda remembered a moment when another student was terrified to tell her family she was gay. Kedarie took her aside. “He told her to live her own life,” encouraging her to come out to her family, Shaunda said.

Shaunda said at school, the teen moved easily between identities. “He definitely would be Kandicee all the time; you probably got Kandicee here more than you got Kedarie,” Shaunda said. “He was a beautiful person, whether he had on jeans or a skirt that day.”

Kedarie and Shaunda used to sit in her office and talk about bounce queen Big Freedia, who has a reality show that Kedarie watched often. “We would always laugh, I would say, ‘I’m gonna see you on TV one day,’” to which Kedarie would respond, while “swinging” their weave, “‘I’m gonna be on TV one day, and have a show like Big Freedia, but I’m gonna be better than Big Freedia.’”

“Kedarie was a free spirit. His light was blown out a little too soon,” Shaunda said. “God let him come into my life for a reason. ... He is missed every day.”

On the eight-month anniversary of Kedarie’s death, friends lit up their social media feeds with memories and comments like, “8 months and still no justice for my diva R.I.H. KEDARIE A.K.A. KANDICEE WITH 2 EEs,” and, “I love you baby, continue to rest easy diva && keep watchin over us we miss you down here.”

Kedarie was shot multiple times, and their body was found in an alley in March.

— Anna Swartz

name: Amos Beede
bio:
Amos Beede, 38, was a stocky guy, with reddish hair and a wide smile. Friends and community members in Burlington, Vermont, remember Amos as “fiercely loyal,” the kind of person who “got into people’s hearts quickly.”

Julia Berberan, a coordinator at the Pride Center of Vermont, first met Amos a few weeks before his death, when he came into the center seeking help for a friend who had been a victim of domestic violence. “That was definitely a constant theme — him going out of his way to help people,” she said.

At the waterfront vigil the center held for Amos soon after his death, “so many people came forward” to share stories, Julia said. B.J. Farman, a friend of who spoke at the vigil, described Amos' “big soft spot for dogs” and his dedication to helping those in his community. B.J. said Amos had lots of plans for programs he wanted to help create, like a “pit bull and parolee” program to bring dogs together with formerly incarcerated people. “If I could talk to Amos one more time, I would tell him once more that his ideas mattered,” B.J. said at the vigil. “His life mattered. He mattered.”

Amos’ mother, Barb, said that as a child, Amos “wanted to please everyone all the time.” She remembered him, at 10 or 11 years old, volunteering at local nursing homes. But “he had a lot of difficulties growing up,” she said. Amos experienced self-harm and drug addiction, and there were long stretches, Barb said, where she and her child didn’t speak. But when he came out to her as trans, she saw a “big change.”

“He called and says, ‘Mom, what do you think about me changing to male?’ I said, ‘Whatever makes you happy,’ and bingo, he became happy,” Barb said. She and her son grew closer than they had ever been. Suddenly, she said, “He had to call me all the time, just to say I love you. ... It might be 7 o’clock in the morning, it might be 11 o’clock at night.” She gave him a dog, whom he named “Nude.” He told his mother it was so he could say, when people asked him what he was up to, “I’m walking Nude downtown.”

Barb could name a number of people whom Amos had impacted: He bought groceries for a woman living in the same motel as him when he realized she couldn’t feed her children; the local bank tellers all knew Amos by name and told Barb they missed his smile. Amos used to ask his mother for baked goods as Christmas presents every year, just so he could give away her fudge and cheesecake to his friends.

Amos died after being beaten in May, allegedly by five people who attacked him at a homeless encampment where Amos sometimes went to visit friends.

— Anna Swartz

name: TT Saffore
bio:
T.T. Saffore, 28, was a friend to anyone who knew her — and nearly everyone did. "If you lived in Chicago, you knew who she was, period," said LaSaia Wade, founder and director of the Tennessee Transgender Justice Project. "She was friendly, she knew everyone. She took care of everyone."

T.T.'s close friend Jaliyah Armstrong said she had a “rocky” relationship with her family because of the “lifestyle she lived for who she wanted to be.” According to Jaliyah, T.T. had been living with her sister, who had taken care of her for most of her life, until she got into an argument with her sister’s boyfriend and was kicked out.

LaSaia said she admired 28-year-old T.T. because she participated in survival sex work, a practice that's typically denigrated despite it often being many trans women's only option to feed, clothe and house themselves.

"Her family had let her down, but [T.T.] wouldn't let herself fall,” she said. “She was doing what she had to do to survive."

Jaliyah remembered meeting T.T. when they were both in a Chicago prison about seven years ago. “She would just check on me and keep me laughing when I was down,” she said. “Whenever she saw me she’d say, ‘Hey, sis, you look cute, you got a cigarette?’”

In return for cigarettes, Jaliyah would send T.T. cookies or peanut butter. “It was just the small things, even when she didn’t have much to give,” she said.

T.T. was found dead in Chicago’s Garfield Park in September. Her throat had been cut.

Jaliyah said she wants justice for her friend — and she’s not alone. Her death sparked the creation of a new anti-violence organization, the Chicago Black Transgender and Gender Nonconforming Collective. In early October, the collective organized a vigil that used the hashtag #TurnUpForTT — a hashtag that captures the spirit of T.T. and of all the other black trans women who, LaSaia notes, should be celebrated in life, not just death.

"A lot of people want to give us flowers after we die and say, 'You were an amazing person, you were beautiful,'" she said. "But the vigil was a reminder that black trans women are here, we’ve been here and we’ll continue to be here."

— Marie Solis

name: Brandi Bledsoe
bio:
Brandi Bledsoe, 32, of Cleveland, expressed herself through her writing. Close friends remember her always having a notebook in hand, working on a short story or a novel. Her favorite genre was fantasy; she loved to write about supernatural or paranormal creatures, including vampires and fairies.

When she wasn’t writing, Brandi read voraciously, mostly fantasy and supernatural novels. She even had plans to co-write a novel with her best friend.

She often dyed her hair in eye-catching colors. She sported blonde streaks as well as red or purple highlights in her straight, black hair.

Brandi also looked after her friends’ health closely: She hated smoking and encouraged friends to quit, even to the point of hiding cigarettes from them.

Brandi was found dead in a Cleveland driveway in October. She had been shot and experienced head trauma.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: RaeLynn Thomas
bio:
Rae'Lynn Thomas, 28, went by many names: Ray, Rayshawn, Ray Ray and Rayshawna, according to local news station 10TV.

Her aunt Shannon remembered Rae'Lynn, who was from Columbus, Ohio, as being the "life of the party" and a “fashionista” — a label that feels right given her signature vibrant lipstick and hoop earrings.

Rae'Lynn's mother, Renee, remembered her daughter similarly, saying she was always “lively,” “funny” and “loving.” She said she’ll never forget the sound of her daughter’s voice.

“[She] loved to sing and had a beautiful voice,” Renee said. She said Rae'Lynn was an R&B and gospel fan, and would sing Boyz II Men and Mariah Carey around the house or in the shower.

Renee said family came first for Rae'Lynn, who spent much of her time at her aunt’s house, playing games or watching movies.

For her grandmother Diane's birthday in July, Rae'Lynn posted a collage of the two on her Facebook page. The collage included one oversized photo showing Diane as a young woman wearing a big smile not unlike her granddaughter's.

"Thanks, sweetie," commented Diane, writing that the photo was a "glamour shot" from when she was 18 or 19. "I love it."

Rae'Lynn was killed at the hands of Renee’s ex-boyfriend, who called her “the devil” and fatally shot her in August.

Rae'Lynn's voice lives on in a cherished recording her family has of her singing “It’s So Hard to Say Goodbye,” her favorite Boyz II Men song.

— Marie Solis

name: Erykah Tijerina
bio:
Kathleen Tijerina Gonzales remembers, when they were kids, her sister Erykah Tijerina would play with Barbie dolls and stick towels on her head as wigs to simulate long hair.

Erykah was a “mama’s boy,” Kathleen said, and she had become a “great aunt” to her nieces and nephew, whom she loved spending time with.

Family was important to 36-year-old Erykah, and Kathleen remembers Christmas 2015 as a particularly happy time.

“All of us siblings were under one roof. We had such a beautiful and unforgettable time,” Kathleen said, describing fond memories of what she called “girl time fun” — doing each other’s hair and makeup, watching funny movies.

Erykah was found dead in her apartment in El Paso, Texas, in August. Erykah’s sisters told local media at the time they worried she might have been targeted because of her gender.

— Brianna Provenzano

name: Mercedes Successful
bio:
Mercedes Successful’s best friend of 10 years, Ricky, remembers her as a caregiver and the “mother figure” in their close-knit friend group. When she saw friends making bad decisions, Ricky said, Mercedes was the one to say, “You know what guys, you shouldn’t be doing that.”

Originally from Jamaica, 32-year-old Mercedes was a vivacious performer who competed in pageants. Photos of her from the 2014 Gay Caribbean USA Pageant show her dressed in a long, sparkling gown with hair piled high. Mercedes “knew how to do everything,” Ricky said, from cooking to doing hair and makeup.

Shortly before Mercedes’ death, Ricky had planned a trip to Atlanta to celebrate his birthday. Just before the getaway, almost all of his friends canceled on him — except Mercedes. The two went away together, and “she made sure that weekend was a fun weekend,” booking them a room in a luxury hotel. “She didn’t have a single bad bone in her body. She was always helping, helping, helping,” Ricky said. “I just want everyone to know about her, her life here. I feel like she was an angel sent from God to me.”

Mercedes was found shot to death in a Haines City, Florida, parking lot in May.

— Anna Swartz

name: Shante Thompson
bio:
Leading up to when Shante Thompson died, the 34-year-old had apparently tried to warn her mother of the repeated bullying she had been subjected to.

"They were bothering him. They kept on picking on him," Leola Thompson told local news station KHOU. "He was telling me that for a long time, they have been bothering him and bothering him. I've been trying to keep him down from this way."

A friend of Shante’s, 33-year-old Willie Sims, was also killed when, witnesses said, a mob of people swarmed the two on a Houston street in April, according to CBS News.

On an online funeral home guest book, many expressed condolences: One person described Shante as “the most kind-hearted, humble person” they had ever known.

“No matter what the situation was you alway seem to look out for us kids in the neighborhood,” another person, Demerits Drexler, wrote. “I hope you rest easy now and look down on you sisters and the kids. We will never forget you.”

— Brianna Provenzano

name: Quartney "Davia / Dawsonn" Yochum
bio:
Quartney Yochum was a bright light in the lives of everyone who knew her.

“He was always happy and smiling, even when he was a kid — in all the pictures you see, he’s always smiling,” Kim Brown-Yochum, Quartney’s mother, said.

As an adult, Quartney exuded the same warmth. According to Kim, the 32-year-old managed two women’s recovery shelters, where she had a blast chatting and joking with the other residents.

“She had the biggest heart in the world,” Kim said. “She would help anybody. She would let homeless people come in and shower, as long as they cleaned up their mess.”

Kim said the void Quartney left behind has been impossible to fill.

“My doctor said when a husband loses his wife, he’s a widower; when a wife loses her husband, she’s a widow; when a child loses their parents, they’re orphans,” Kim said. “What is a mother when she loses her child? There’s no name for it, but she’s broken-hearted forever.”

Quartney was shot to death outside her apartment building, allegedly by an abusive ex-partner, on March 23.

— Brianna Provenzano

name: Devin Diamond
bio:
Devin Diamond, 20, was posthumously identified in some reports as Goddess, a name she was given after her death by trans poet and writer Venus Selenite. George Melichar, a co-worker and friend, remembered her kooky sense of humor and the way she joked around when they went out together. “I would always laugh whenever she would drink because she would chew ice more than she would drink her beverage,” George said. “I would say, ‘Why don’t you just get a cup of ice?’”

Devin was a magnetic presence. “She was amazing, she looked awesome in a dress,” George said. “Most women wished they looked as good in a dress as she did.” Pictures on social media show Devin with long red hair, head tilted to the side as she posed for a selfie.

George said Devin was a hard worker who “didn’t feel entitled to anything” and was saving up for a car. She sometimes spoke to George about the pain she felt when she encountered bigotry and ignorance. “I remember her crying one day about how she didn’t understand ... why people would hate her for wanting to be who she was,” he said. George said his friend told him she didn't mind using her birth name of Devin, because it was gender neutral.

“If there was anything I would want people to know about her, it’s that I loved her and she was loved,” George said. “For all the people who gave her shit, she still conquered every day as a proud woman.”

Devin’s mother, Antionette Diamond, told the Times-Picayune one of the last texts she received from Devin had been a picture of the keys to Devin’s new apartment — she had just gotten a job at a Walmart and moved into the new place. Antionette told the Times-Picayune she had gotten that text the same day her younger child graduated from kindergarten: "We were all so happy.”

Devin’s body was found in a burning car in June, and evidence showed she had died from blunt force trauma.

— Anna Swartz

name: Maya Young
bio:
Maya Young, 25, had a distinctive birthmark that gave her face two different skin tones. Maya's friends gave her nicknames like “Twix” or “Milano cookie” because of her skin and because she was sweet.

Maya was studying to become a nurse, but dropped out because of troubles with her family. She then turned to sex work to make money.

Maya fell in love with geek culture and role-playing games after playing Magic: The Gathering. She loved video games and outplayed all her friends, often beating the game before they could. Her favorite video games were the Final Fantasy series, especially Final Fantasy 13, which she would play from morning through the night. She also loved martial arts and enjoyed watching films like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

On Feb. 20, Maya was found on the streets of north Philadelphia after being stabbed multiple times. She died in the hospital.

— Mathew Rodriguez

name: Keyonna Blakeney
bio:
Iva Wallace remembers her friend and former classmate Keyonna Blakeney as a brave girl with a big heart who was never afraid to speak her mind in high school.

“She was a very outspoken person when we met, and then when I got to know her, she was a very kindhearted person,” Iva said. “She wasn’t afraid to speak out on problems.”

Although some teachers at school gave Keyonna — then in the midst of transitioning — a hard time for wearing wigs and using the girl’s bathroom, Iva said her warmth and sense of humor never wavered.

“She would make anyone in the room laugh,” Iva said.

A few years before Keyonna died, the two had a conversation in the locker room of their high school about shared pain that Iva said she’ll never forget.

“I had been going through some body issues and she was transforming,” Iva said. “She just turned to me and said, ‘We’re never gonna fight our battles alone.’ She said she would fight my battles, and I would fight hers. That was the last conversation that we had face-to-face.”

“There will never be another like her,” Iva added. “She was one of a kind.”[bu]

Keyonna was found dead i[bv][bw]n April in a hotel room in Rockville, Maryland, with trauma to her upper body. She had celebrated her 22nd birthday just days earlier.

— Brianna Provenzano

name: Dee Whigham
bio:
Dee Whigham, 25, dedicated her life to caring for others. She worked as a registered nurse at Forrest Health, a hospital in Hattiesburg, Mississippi, where she took on extra shifts and overtime to support her mother, according to a GoFundMe page set up to raise funds for funeral costs.

"Dee was a very, very happy and free-spirited person — always down to help someone in their time of need even if she had [too] much on her plate already," said Melody Jones, a close friend who met Dee in nursing school. She said Dee would help her study for exams while they were in school.

Melody said Dee was often assigned to the patients who had bipolar disorder because of how “vibrant” and “nurturing” she was.

“I think every patient Dee had was her favorite, and she was their favorite,” she said.

In photos, Dee's hair is long and flowing, framing her face in shiny layers. Melody said Dee came to her house regularly to get her hair done by her girlfriend at the time, Nikea — the only person Dee would let touch her hair. “She would call me and ask, ‘Is your girlfriend in town?’ even after we broke up,” Melody said. They would order pizza and drink wine, talking and laughing until the early morning hours. Nikeya did Dee's hair the same night she was killed.

On July 23, Dee was found stabbed to death while visiting the Gulf Coast Black Rodeo in Biloxi, Mississippi. U.S. Navy sailor Dwanya Hickerson has been charged with her death.

— Marie Solis

name: Deeniquia Dodds
bio:
Deeniquia Dodds, 22, went by Dee Dee to friends and family. Joeann Lewis, her mother, remembers the day Dee Dee told her she wanted to be known as Deeniquia, when she was 21. “She just said, ‘Ma, my name is not Dee Dee anymore; my name is Deeniquia,’” Joeann recalled. “She wasn’t ashamed to say it — she was happy.” As a child, she often wore “something tied around her head,” like a scarf or a head wrap, to pretend she had long hair.

Earline Budd, a transgender activist working in the Washington, D.C., area, remembered Deeniquia as the kind of person who “always liked to make people laugh.”

“Oh my God, she was just joyous,” Earline remembered. “She just simply wanted to be loved, and to be a part of the community.”

Deeniquia dealt with homelessness, and Deeniquia had sought Earline out for help finding a job and a place to live. “She faced some of the obstacles that most transgender people face,” Earline said, “there’s usually not a lot of options in terms of housing.”

Earline remembered the vigil held for Deeniquia: “Folks came out in the rain, to just speak her name. ... It sent chills through the community.”

Deeniquia was shot on the Fourth of July and spent nine days on life support before she died.

— Anna Swartz

name: Reese Walker
bio:
Those who knew 32-year-old Reese — or "Reecey" — Walker, say she lived up to her name.

Walker's mom, Shari, told the Huffington Post that she named her daughter after Reese's peanut butter cups, which she craved endlessly during her pregnancy. Her loved ones say she was just as sweet as her name suggested.

"You got fresh air when you got Reese," her sister, Shampayne, told the site. "She had an essence that pulled people in."

According to the Advocate, a now-deleted GoFundMe page read, "Reese, 'like the candy,' as she introduced herself, was a loving, playful spirit who only wanted the best for others. She would have given her last piece of bread to make sure someone else was not hungry."

After she came out as trans in ninth grade, Reese did everything she could to make her community a safer place for people of all gender identities and sexual orientations. The Huffington Post described her as a "trailblazer" for trans youth at her high school in Wichita, Kansas, where she helped create a new anti-bullying policy. The school newspaper article about the initiative had been cut out, framed and hung in the school for years.

Reese had aspirations to continue helping others for the rest of her life.

A friend, identified only as Victoria, told local news station KAKE, "[She] wanted to get a degree in psychology or social work to try to become a counselor to help other people try to get through some of the same struggles [she] had been through.”

— Marie Solis
